>

 scientific/methodical approach in demonstrating ability 
> to discover pat=
terns, a priori known patterns, before attempting to 
> demonstrate a "kill=
er-application", for which there is no known 
> figure of merit to compare =
"ability to discover patterns", is 
> disturbing, and expecting an inordina=
te level of faith on the part of 
> the reader.
> 
> The lack of any compar=
ative computational cost data is equally 
> disturbing, and begs the questi=
on, especially since there appears to 
> be a growing body of user experien=
ce that the computational cost is

p-front going in rather than

Andy, I'm trying =
to figure out what's bothering you.  You express
impatience that every poss=
ible question has not been answered within
one year of the debut of a compl=
etely new methodology.  It verges on
paranoia to suggest that we are "withh=
olding" information (the source
code is released; anyone can perform any ex=
periment that they wish). 
I suppose you just don't realize how much effort=
 goes into running
experiments and writing papers. 

Notice that others in =
this group ask questions that are couched as
friendly discussion.  Yet you =
take the attitude that someone is hiding
something from you and you are the=
refore "disturbed."  

You should change your tone.  Instead of attacking t=
he source for not
having answered every question that you have and performe=
d every
experiment that you personally believe we should ever perform, why =
not
put it more like, "It would be interesting to see if..."  or "One
exper=
iment I'd like to perform is..."  or "An interesting question is
whether...=
" In other words, what is accomplished by your aggressive,
confrontational =
demeanor?

I remember hearing once, though I do not remember the source, an=

interesting quote on scientific research.  To paraphrase: "Good
scientific=
 research answers hard questions.  However, the best
scientific research ra=
ises entirely new questions that we never could
have even asked before."  T=
hink of quantum physics.  The uncertainty
principle has led to endless disc=
ussion of paradoxes and
impossibilities, with no end in sight, but we do no=
t see people
accusing Heisenberg of trying to hide the "truth."  Instead, i=
t is a
credit to his discovery that we are now asking such profound questio=
ns.

So let me suggest to you that you change your tone and drop the
confro=
ntational demeanor.  That is not an appropriate way to speak to
colleagues,=
 or to anyone else for that matter, and I sincerely hope to
maintain the ex=
ceptional positive atmosphere this group has maintained
throughout 5 years =
(believe it or not!) of fruitful and interesting
discussion.

Let me also a=
dd that I am not the moderator (who is Derek James, who
has done an excelle=
nt job), and therefore this is just my personal
suggestion.

ken
